column16: The Guardian - State of Emergency declared in Liberia and Sierra Leone / ActionAid - Ebola Crisis Update
column18: Sierra Leone declares a state of emergency which leads to the closure of schools, markets and any gathering not related to the fight against Ebola alongside the quarantining of affected communities. Inititally Public Emergency Act was planned to end 31/10/14 but will most likely continue.

column16: Channel News Asia - Sierra Leone Law Ebola Victims
column18: Outlawed the “harbouring” of Ebola victims - risk a jail sentence of up to two years.

column16: UNMEER - External Situation Report
column18: A standard operating procedure (SOP) for enforcing roadblocks and quarantines has been approved by the Government of Sierra Leone with training of 4,000 - 5,000 officers nationwide.

column16: Acaps - Global Emergency Overview
column18: Legislation was passed imposing a jail term of up to six months for anyone entering or leaving Ebola-affected areas without medical authorisation. Any sport involving physical contact was also prohibited.

column16: Vox - Lockdown
column18: Entire population not allowed to leave homes for 3 days to reduce spread.

column16: The Guardian - As Ebola closes schools in Africa
column18: Schools have not opened since 9 September, and authorities are suggesting they may remain closed for three months or more.

column16: Reuters - Sierra Leone Shuts Borders
column18: Closed schools, nightclubs and cinemas in Kailahun.

column16: http://reliefweb.int/sites/reliefweb.int/files/resources/b-acaps_bn_ebola_west_africa_impact_protection_14_oct_2014.pdf

column16: AllAfrica - Liberia: Stay Home Orders Extended

column16: BBC News - Ebola: Liberia Shuts Schools to Tackle Outbreak

column16: Al Jazeera - Liberia Declares Curfew
column18: Night-time curfew of 21.00-06.00 imposed. No mentioned of the breach consequences.

column16: AllAfrica - Government lifts quarantine and adjust curfew
column18: Night-time curfew updated to 23.00-06.00 for more reasonable hours longer term.

column16: Acaps - Global Emergency Overview
column18: Parliament criminalised the deliberate concealment of information about people with contagious diseases such as Ebola and HIV.

column16: Acaps - Global Emergency Overview / UNMEER - External Situation Report
column18: All markets in border areas are closed until further notice. As of 13 October, around 60 percent of markets outside Monrovia have closed or scaled down.

column16: International SOS - Latest News
column18: Journalists must now secure written permission from the Ministry of Health if they want to take photographs or conduct interviews at Ebola healthcare facilities.

column16: Africa Review - Guinea postpones reopening of schools / UN News Centre - UN budget committee approves funding
column18: Government announces schools will not open for the new school year until ebola has subsided. Primary schools, secondary schools and universities are closed.

column16: Guinea News - Health Emergency Declaration in Guinea
column18: Guinea declares a state of emergency and non-specific 'cordon sanitaire' declared with restriction of movement mentioned.

column16: Acaps - Global Emergency Overview
column18: Ban announced on moving bodies from own town to another until the end of the epidemic.

column16: News Observer - Ebola surging in
column18: Authorities restricting access.

column16: Polity - Ebola outbreak reaches Senegal, riots break out in Guinea
column18: 24-hour curfew imposed after riots broke out in response to health workers spraying market with disinfectant without notice.

column16: International SOS - Latest News
column18: WHO quarantine zone.

column16: BBC - Nigiera declares national emergency
column18: Nigeria declares state of emergency and commits funds to containing Ebola outbreak. On 20 October, WHO declares Nigeria as Ebola-free.

column16: BBC - Nigeria closes all schools
column18: The re-opening of schools was postponed until 22 September (earlier than original plan of 13 October) due to Ebola concerns.

column16: Agence France-Presse - Most, but not all, of Nigeria’s students back to school after Ebola lay off
column18: School ban remains in Lagos until 8 October.

column18: Senegal's Minister of Interior requested the closure of 16 weekly markets along the border with Guinea.

column16: BBC News - Senegal Defends Guinea Border Closure
column18: Senegal has re-closed land border with Guinea. Originally closed in February 2014 but then re-opened in May 2014. Supposedly humanitarian transport is allowed through but this has been disputed by those in the field.

column18: Chad closed land border with Nigeria at Lake Chad. On 20/9/14, Chad opened a corridor along the border with Nigeria to permit trade between the two countries.

column16: IRIN - West Africa gears up to contain Ebola spread
column18: Cameroon closed land border with Nigeria. Note refugees fleeing Boko Haram attacks have been crossing the border.

column16: International SOS - Travel security advisories - Flight bans and closures
column18: Kenya closed Suam border crossing with Uganda due to reports of an Ebola-related death in Bukwo district (Uganda).

column16: Reuters - Mauritania closes border with Mali over Ebola
column18: Government of Mauritania has ordered the closing of all border crossings with Mali after its first reported case of Ebola.

column16: AllAfrica - Ivory Coast Imposed Economic Blockade
column18: Ivory Coast temporarily blocked access to sea ports being used as a trans-shipment point under the ebola outbreak.

column16: Channel News Asia - Seaport Restrictions
column18: Liberia denying any crew to disembark at seaports until Ebola epidemic subsided.

column16: International SOS - Travel security advisories - Flight bans and closures
column18: Cameroon closed sea border with Nigeria.

column16: International SOS - Travel security advisories - Flight bans and closures
column18: Senegal closed its sea border to vessels from Guinea, Liberia and Sierra Leone.
